details.description:
Hannah Redler is an interdisciplinary curator and producer who works with artists and researchers on projects that explore shared areas of interest, diversion and conversation between art, science and technology for galleries, museums, digital space and other public spaces. As Associate Curator in Residence at the ODI she co-directs, with artist Julie Freeman, the ODI’s art programme, Data as Culture, which critically engages with data, open data, code and networked culture through artists’ residencies, exhibitions, events and commissions at the ODI and with international partners.

Hannah’s work as an independent curator and art adviser includes developing projects and formulating creative strategies with organisations including Science Gallery, London, Wellcome Collection, The Institute of Physics, Tate Modern, The Lowry, and the Natural History Museum. She combines these roles with teaching on commissioning and curating contemporary art, histories of art and technology, interdisciplinary programming, arts fundraising and informal learning in museums.

From 2005-2014 Hannah was Head of Arts Programme at the Science Museum, where she led teams commissioning and curating a broad programme of art and photography interventions, exhibitions, programmes and participatory projects with established and emerging artists working within a variety of media and artistic strategies. Prior to working as a curator Hannah co-founded and co-directed Studio Fish Digital Media (1994 - 2001), an artist-led digital media company which provided innovative software solutions across arts and industry sectors.

Hannah will be discussing 'is open data really open to all' at the ODI Summit 2016. The conversation will be convened by artists Julie Freeman and Gary Stewart, along with Hannah. Other contributors will include artists Larry Achiampong, Natasha Caruana and Alison Craighead (Thomson & Craighead), musician, artist and creative technologist Alex McLean, producer, educator and artist Derek Richards and curator, artist and PhD Researcher at FACT, Liverpool Sam Skinner.
